hero.title: Framework: Mind / Market / Price Action
hero.subtitle: Better trading is rarely about more tricks - it's about a stable loop: perception -> execution -> review. This framework breaks skill into three pillars and turns them into weekly drills with audit-ready outputs. You learn to describe context, write falsification points before entry, size risk consistently, and review behavior with evidence. Rebuild cognition and execution first; strategy details come last.
highlights: Three pillars mapped to a weekly training cadence.
Falsification-first thinking for every idea and entry.
Audit-ready outputs: checklists, logs, and review notes.
hero.risk: Educational content only. Not investment advice; trading involves substantial risk.

title: Framework
lead: Three pillars, a weekly training loop, and audit-ready outputs. Build an operating system for repeatable execution.

modules.title: Three core modules — switch the view with one click
modules.lead: These three modules act as buttons. Tap one to switch the content below.

mind.title: Mind & discipline
mind.slogan: Separate emotion and impulse from the decision chain so execution stays repeatable under pressure.
mind.outputHint: Pre-trade checklist / Execution scorecard / Cooldown + review templates
mind.position: Fix the “I know what to do but still fail” problem: maintain rule execution, risk consistency, and a review loop under uncertainty.
scenarios: Relaxing rules and oversizing after wins
Decision fatigue leading to random entries

pillars.title: Trigger recognition & cooldown
pillars.desc: Identify emotional triggers and set a cooldown window.

pillars.title: Review & corrective actions
pillars.desc: Use data to correct, not willpower.

steps.title: Trigger list
steps.definition: List 10 high-frequency loss-of-control scenarios with concrete detail.

steps.title: Execution scorecard
steps.definition: Record 50 trades with focus on rule adherence.

steps.title: Correction plan
steps.definition: Define alternatives for 3 frequent errors and track for 2 weeks.

drills.title: Impulse delay: wait 90 seconds before any order
Only A setups: execute A setups only
Post-loss cooldown: rest 15 minutes after a losing trade
Review three questions: Did I follow rules? Which rule broke? What is the replacement action?

antipatterns: Treating “mindset” as slogans without process or data
Judging only PnL, not rule adherence
Doubling down after losses to “win it back”

faq.q: Q: Is poor execution a personality issue?
faq.a: A: Mostly a system issue — replace willpower with gates and process.

faq.q: Q: How long until it works?
faq.a: A: Track rule adherence first. Stabilize before advancing.

market.title: Market structure
market.slogan: Define environment and boundaries first, then plan entries and management.
market.outputHint: Regime tags / Structure map / Entry thesis card
market.position: Fix the “see it, take it” habit: break the market into structure, phase, and boundaries to make fewer, higher-quality decisions.
scenarios: Can’t tell range vs trend vs acceleration
Obsessing over entries while missing regime shifts

pillars.title: Risk location
pillars.desc: Define where you’re wrong inside structure.

steps.title: Daily structure marking
steps.definition: Mark highs, lows, and ranges for 10 straight days.

steps.title: Write the boundary
steps.definition: For 30 trades, write “if wrong, where?” before entry.

steps.title: Management rules
steps.definition: Backtest/review 50 trades and write if/then rules.

drills.title: Three-pass reading: structure → state → key levels
Key-level review: review only failed trades near key levels
Regime shift log: record signals from range to trend

metrics: Rule violations near key levels (per week)
antipatterns: Treating structure as decoration without verifiable rules
Immediate reversal after a sweep at key levels

faq.a: A: Use a marking template + sample library to compress subjectivity into repeatable actions.

faq.q: Q: Do I need complex tools?
faq.a: A: No. Templates and simple labels are enough; consistency matters most.

price.title: Price Action core
price.slogan: Organize structure by force and location, express decisions with falsification.
price.outputHint: Candle grammar card / Falsification template / Location x Force matrix
price.position: Move from pattern memory to grammar understanding: candles are outcomes of behavior, not signals. Use fewer concepts to express a clearer evidence chain.
scenarios: Patterns look clear but results are inconsistent
Stops are random and falsification is vague
Jumping in on long wicks or engulfing candles

pillars.title: Force
pillars.desc: Who is pushing and is it sustained?

pillars.title: Location
pillars.desc: Where does it happen inside structure?

drills.title: Falsification-only: look at charts and write where it fails
Location constraint: compare win rate of same pattern by location

antipatterns: Treating patterns as “signals” and ignoring location/structure
Stops by gut feel with vague invalidation
Reading a candle without the surrounding narrative

faq.q: Q: How much candlestick theory do I need?
faq.a: A: Less but precise — write force/location/falsification as a grammar.

faq.q: Q: Is falsification the same as a stop loss?
faq.a: A: Falsification defines where you’re wrong; stops should align with that risk expression.

triangle.title: You cannot maximize win rate, R:R, and frequency at the same time
triangle.lead: Every trading system prioritizes two corners and concedes the third.

winRate.title: Win rate first
winRate.desc: Higher win rate usually means smaller targets or heavier filtering. Frequency or R must shrink.
winRate.note: Best for stability and drawdown control phases.

rr.title: R:R first
rr.desc: Bigger R requires waiting and tolerating pullbacks. Win rate or frequency declines.

freq.title: Frequency first
freq.desc: High frequency means more noise. Win rate or R must compress to stay viable.
freq.note: Fits fast training with strict risk control.

body: The impossible triangle means you cannot keep win rate, R:R, and frequency high at the same time. Raising one corner compresses another.

System design starts by admitting the constraint. If you want a high win rate, accept smaller R or lower frequency; if you want high R, accept lower win rate and longer waits; if you want high frequency, accept smaller R or lower win rate.
Respecting the facts is not compromise — it is matching your goal to the right timeframe and execution style.

timeframes.title: Facts across timeframes

items.v: Noisier and faster. Frequency is easier, but win rate or R must be compressed. Tight stops demand discipline.
Structure improves but still high frequency. Win rate and R require stricter filtering.
Lower frequency, more stable structure. R opens up, but waiting costs rise.
Fewer signals but higher quality. R and stability improve at the expense of speed.

timeframes.focus: Focus suggestion: choose your primary corner (win rate / R / frequency) first, then choose timeframe and rules. Don't chase the all-max triangle.

mind.summary: Separate impulses from the decision chain. Build gates and scorecards so execution stays repeatable under pressure.

market.summary: Write the environment and boundaries first, then decide. Turn narrative, location, and risk into reviewable context logs.

price.summary: Organize structure by force and location, constrain decisions with falsification, and formalize entry/exit into auditable SOPs.

loop.lead: A fixed cadence turns ideas into outputs: input -> break down -> execute -> review -> iterate.

s1.v: Collect context: regime, narrative, locations, risk environment.

s2.v: Write a clean claim: force, location, and falsification.

s3.v: Run the gate, size by risk, and log decisions.

s4.v: Audit behavior: violations, exits, and evidence quality.

s5.v: Change one variable and re-run the loop next week.

audit.lead: A scorecard makes the process reviewable: consistency, risk, review quality, and stable perception.

a1.title: Consistency
a1.desc: Do gates, risk, and exits look the same across trades?

a2.title: Risk control
a2.desc: Is risk per trade consistent - and reduced when the environment changes?

a3.title: Review quality
a3.desc: Do you produce written reviews with corrective actions?

a4.title: Perception stability
a4.desc: Can you explain different markets with one framework under stress?
